content.title: Alcohol Pharmacology: Effects on Sleep and Cognition
content.summary: The pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of ethanol, with emphasis on effects on sleep architecture, cognitive function, and next-day impairment
key_points: Alcohol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) at ~0.015% BAC/hour
Alcohol disrupts sleep architecture - reduces REM sleep, causes fragmentation
Even moderate drinking (2-3 drinks) impairs next-day cognitive performance
Alcohol causes dehydration via ADH (antidiuretic hormone) suppression
Congeners in darker drinks contribute to hangover severity
Effects on GABA and glutamate systems produce CNS depression
Memory consolidation impaired by alcohol's effects on hippocampus

statement.text: Ethanol is a central nervous system depressant that affects multiple neurotransmitter systems, particularly enhancing GABA and inhibiting glutamate. Despite initial sedative effects, alcohol disrupts sleep architecture by suppressing REM sleep and causing second-half fragmentation. Cognitive effects persist beyond alcohol clearance, impairing memory consolidation and next-day executive function.
statement.formal: Cognitive Impairment = f(Alcohol Dose × Duration) + Sleep Disruption + Dehydration - Recovery Time

explanation.intuition: Alcohol is the one substance that makes you feel relaxed and sleepy initially, but borrows against tomorrow's performance. The drink that helps you unwind tonight will make you sleep poorly and think less clearly tomorrow. Understanding the pharmacology helps identify where the breakeven point is.
explanation.key_insight: Alcohol disrupts sleep even when you 'pass out' quickly. The sedative effect wears off after 4-5 hours, causing the second half of the night to be fragmented and lacking restorative REM sleep. This is why you feel unrested after drinking even if you 'slept' 8 hours.

definitions_glossary.standard_drink: 14g of pure alcohol = 12oz beer (5%) = 5oz wine (12%) = 1.5oz spirits (40%)
definitions_glossary.blood_alcohol_concentration: Percentage of alcohol in blood; legal limit 0.08% in most US states
definitions_glossary.alcohol_dehydrogenase: Primary liver enzyme that metabolizes ethanol to acetaldehyde
definitions_glossary.REM_rebound: Increased REM sleep occurring after alcohol wears off, causing vivid dreams/restlessness
definitions_glossary.congeners: Byproducts in alcoholic beverages that contribute to hangovers (darker drinks have more)
definitions_glossary.ADH_hormone: Antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) - suppressed by alcohol, causing diuresis
definitions_glossary.hangover: Post-intoxication symptoms: headache, fatigue, nausea, cognitive impairment

pharmacokinetics.absorption: Rapidly absorbed from stomach (20%) and small intestine (80%); food slows absorption
pharmacokinetics.distribution: Water-soluble; distributes to all tissues; crosses blood-brain barrier freely

metabolism.primary_pathway: Alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) → acetaldehyde → aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH) → acetate
metabolism.rate: ~0.015% BAC per hour (one standard drink per hour)
metabolism.genetic_variation: ADH and ALDH variants affect metabolism rate and flushing response

pharmacokinetics.elimination: First-order kinetics at low doses; approaches zero-order at higher concentrations

pharmacodynamics.GABA_system: Potentiates GABA-A receptor activity → CNS depression, anxiolysis, sedation
pharmacodynamics.glutamate_system: Inhibits NMDA glutamate receptors → impaired memory formation
pharmacodynamics.dopamine_system: Increases dopamine in reward pathways → reinforcing effects

sleep_effects.sleep_onset: Reduced latency to sleep onset (sedative effect)
sleep_effects.REM_suppression: Reduced REM sleep in first half of night
sleep_effects.fragmentation: Increased awakenings in second half as alcohol metabolizes
sleep_effects.overall_quality: Despite longer 'sleep' time, restorative value reduced

next_day: Effects persist even after BAC returns to zero

quantity_limits.low_risk: 1-2 drinks maximum; stop 3+ hours before bed

timing.early_stopping: No alcohol within 3-4 hours of intended sleep time
timing.rate_limiting: Maximum 1 drink per hour (liver processing rate)
timing.pre_eating: Substantial meal before/with drinking slows absorption

drink_selection.lower_ABV: Light beer, wine spritzers reduce total alcohol intake
